captions.text:
All the new games I&#39;ve played lately have
had a distinctly rodent-y theme.

I don&#39;t know why rats and mice are suddenly
the in thing, maybe &#39;cos spring cleaning has

begun and I finally chased out that weasel
colony that was living in my favourite stack
of damp newspapers.

First I played Moss on VR, where you play
a brave little mouse, but I figured we did

some VR fairly recently and the tech&#39;s still
only as relevant to most people&#39;s lives as
the British space programme.

Then Steam started pushing Vermintide 2 at
me which is mainly about killing rat dudes.
&quot;Look, Yahtz!

An exciting horde fighting game where you
enter the rich Warhammer universe and start
up your own pest control business.&quot;

So I played that for a while and it brought
many an excited cry to my lips, mostly sounding
like this: Isn&#39;t this just Left 4 Dead?

Erm, no, it&#39;s Vermintide 2, see, completely
different name.
No really, this is just Left 4 Dead.

Four players, hordes of weak enemies, there&#39;s
the hunter, there&#39;s the smoker, there&#39;s the

spitter - don&#39;t be silly, Yahtz, Left 4 Dead
is a shooter whereas this has a lot of melee
combat.

Oh right, forgive me, let me reassess that
- isn&#39;t this just Left 4 Dead 2?

Except with levels and loot boxes and crafting
and all the usual live service manipulative
hornswaggle?
Not the best sales pitch, is it.

Hey kids, did you like Left 4 Dead 2 but wish
that it held you in more contempt?

So then Ghost of a Tale caught my eye, which
is a plucky little indie game that came out

of nowhere where you play a scared little
mouse in a big rat fantasy castle and which

before you say anything is a totally, totally
distinct entity from the Redwall books.

I&#39;ll just say the title again because you&#39;ve
no doubt forgotten it already - Ghost of a

Tale, which I know sounds like it could be
a pun, but I&#39;ve gone over it eight times with

a set square and I&#39;m damned if I can find
one.

There is a ghost in it and most of the characters
possess tails but if that&#39;s a pun then a cardboard
box full of warmed-up dead fish is a harem.

Anyway, the main character is Tilo, a mouse
minstrel imprisoned in the castle dungeon

who must embark on a quest to find his wife,
also a mouse, his mouse spouse if you will,
and escape.

The game that follows likes to refer to itself
as an RPG, which is very cute, like a small

child wearing their mum&#39;s coat, but doesn&#39;t
have much in the way of RPG elements.

You mainly stealth around, until you find
the armour that turns guards friendly, after
which you just... around.

What attracted me to Ghost of a Tale was that
it appeared to want to stick to its mouse
guns.

A lot of games with Stealth on the menu only
have it as a starter dish and it devolves

into a straight combat main course at the
slightest fuckup, but Tilo isn&#39;t a fighter,

his ability to knock out guards with thrown
bottles to the bonce notwithstanding but they

don&#39;t stay knocked out for long, and he can
only scurry away to find a nice toilet to
hide in.

I respect the way the game&#39;s focus on stealth
enhances the story, establishing Tilo as physically

all but useless and getting by on raw cunning,
and yet, the game also doesn&#39;t kick you in

the teeth the instant you get spotted &#39;cos
there are hiding places everywhere and it&#39;s

easy to scurry off like a shy roommate furtively
darting to the bathroom in their underpants.

I like how Tilo&#39;s speed, small size and climbing
ability give him options for bypassing guard

patrols other than having to just creep along
behind them the whole time like a toadying
lackey with an enthusiasm for farts.

But I still have some nitpicks with the stealth
- the guards&#39; attention meters still go up

even when you&#39;re creeping, and only go down
when you stop, so you might as well not creep

at all, just sprint-stop-sprint-stop like
an incontinent marathon runner.

Until your stamina runs out, &#39;cos sprinting
chews it up like popcorn, and then all you

can do is maintain a huffy brisk walk away
from pursuing guards like a suburban mother

very offended that the Whole Foods wouldn&#39;t
take their expired coupons.

I&#39;m also a bit iffy about the way the camera
insists on sticking close to your little furry

butt again like it&#39;s into farts because it&#39;s
hard to keep an eye on what&#39;s going on in
the distance.

Less a problem while you&#39;re in a cramped dungeon,
more of one once the game opens up and you

have to start exploring large, confusingly
laid out courtyards.

Or rather, one large, confusingly laid out
courtyard over and over again, because this

is one of those games whose dev team is only
big enough to get about one tenth of the way

towards satisfying your mum, and which could
entirely fit in the back of my car given time

and a hacksaw, so the game has to be economical
with content.

There aren&#39;t that many environments and you
end up going back and forth across them a
lot to complete the quests.
Almost all of which are fetch quests.

It was starting to get a bit disheartening
every time I saw a little speech bubble icon

marking a new friendly NPC &#39;cos I knew another
fucking fetch quest couldn&#39;t be far away.

It&#39;s like some fantasy universe where the
major religion was World of Warcraft and fetch

quests supplanted handshakes as the main form
of greeting.

You escape the dungeon, meet your mysterious
benefactor, and they tell you that they&#39;ll

take care of all the finding your wife business
just as soon as you do their fetch quests.

All of which will splinter off into fractal
fetch quests on the way and would you mind
opening that hatch for a second?

WHOOPS all my pets escaped, another fetch
quest for you!
Well, what do you want, Yahtz?
You&#39;re a scared little mouse.

Fetching stuff is just about your only skill
besides scurrying and adorable nose twitching.
What were you expecting, Ornstein and Smough?
Smoge?
Smoff?

What were you expecting, Ornstein and your
mum?

I get you, viewer, the fetch quests are just
a means to enable the core gameplay, but there

are two little sticking points hanging off
that fact like turds needing to be pinched

off; firstly, the only benefit to most of
the fetch quests is XP, which only levels

you up, which only increases your health,
which is rarely an issue because you&#39;re supposed

to pull up your knickers and scarper at the
first sign of danger, and secondly, whatever

fun can be extracted from the stealth, not
too far into the game you get a rat disguise

that removes the stealth challenge entirely,
and then the fetch quests are all that&#39;s left,

like the bad joke on the lollipop stick that
remains after everything else has been sucked
away.

I probably sound down on the game, and after
a while I was tempted to go back to Vermintide

where I could at least decapitate any rat
who demanded I fetch their pipe and slippers,

but I stuck with Ghost of a Tale because I
think the writing saves it.

The dialogue&#39;s nicely written, it even at
one point made me laugh in an out loud fashion.

That&#39;s right, a literal lol, and it&#39;s a rare
thing for me to literally lol because I&#39;m
jaded and got the tunnelling brain parasites.

And I like the story, the way it starts out
nice and simple - mice good, rats bad, escape

dungeon, find wife, kiss wife, shag wife,
question mark - but as you explore and learn
about the world things get more nuanced.

Not mice good rats bad, maybe mice flawed
rats complicated?

See the rats tend to be dour and brutal and
not the best people to call on if your restaurant&#39;s

got a health inspection due, but there&#39;s also
a nobility to them and they seem to be the
only ones getting shit organised.

Meanwhile, the mice are superficially good-spirited
but in keeping with our stealth activities

lean more towards being sneaky, thieving little
cowards, and I hate their big noses and their

monopolisation of global finance - wait, what
were we talking about?
